study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a high-protein (HP) diet versus a Mediterranean (M) diet on metabolic parameters, particularly insulin resistance and glycemic variability, in insulin-resistant obese women.
results_summary: The HP diet was more effective than the M diet in reducing insulin resistance (lower insulin levels and HOMA-IR) and improving glycemic variability. A panel of 10 microbial genera, including Coprococcus and Lachnoclostridium, was identified as predictive of the difference in glycemic variability between the diets.
population_specificity: Insulin-resistant, obese women (n=16 completed the study).
study_duration: 21 days (crossover trial with two dietary sequences: M-HP or HP-M)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of a high-protein diet combined with exercise on markers of cardiometabolic health in middle-aged adults with obesity.
results_summary: The combined high-protein diet and exercise intervention significantly reduced fat mass, improved lipid profiles, insulin sensitivity, glucose tolerance, and inflammation. The exercise-alone group showed improvements in β-cell function, while the combined intervention had broader metabolic benefits.
population_specificity: Middle-aged adults with obesity

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether exercise combined with a high-protein diet improves muscle function, exercise capacity, and functional physical performance in middle-aged obese adults compared to exercise alone or no intervention.
results_summary: The study found that exercise combined with a high-protein diet significantly improved maximal work rate, peak oxygen consumption, muscle power, and functional physical performance (sit-to-stand and stair-climbing tests) compared to the control group. The high-protein diet group also showed a 12% increase in anaerobic threshold, which was not observed in the exercise-only group.
population_specificity: Middle-aged (50-64 years old) obese adults.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Entresto therapy could protect cardiomyocytes and heart function in cardiorenal syndrome rats fed a high-protein diet by regulating oxidative stress and Mfn2-mediated mitochondrial integrity.
results_summary: The study found that Entresto protected H9C2 cells from H2O2-induced apoptosis, reduced oxidative stress and mitochondrial damage, and improved cardiac function in rats fed a high-protein diet. Downregulation of Mfn2 further enhanced these protective effects.
population_specificity: Cardiorenal syndrome rats fed a high-protein diet and H9C2 cells (a rat cardiomyocyte cell line).
effective_dosage: Entresto (100 mg/kg/day for in vivo study; 12.5 μM for in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a higher-protein diet (double the RDA) compared to standard protein intake affects one-carbon (1C) metabolite status in older men, particularly focusing on homocysteine levels and related metabolites.
results_summary: Both diets reduced plasma homocysteine concentrations. The standard protein diet (RDA) showed specific changes in betaine-dependent remethylation ratios, while the higher-protein diet (2RDA) was associated with altered folate and choline metabolite responses. The health implications of these differential responses remain uncertain.
population_specificity: Older men (age 74 ± 3 years).
effective_dosage: 0.8 g/kg body weight/day (RDA) vs. 1.6 g/kg body weight/day (2RDA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of prolonged high-protein (HP) and low-protein (LP) diets on myocardial [18F]FDG uptake, body weight, and body fat percentage in mice.
results_summary: The study found that myocardial [18F]FDG uptake was unaffected by HP diets but increased with LP diets. HP diets resulted in lower body weight and body fat percentage compared to chow and LP diets, with stronger effects observed in C57BL mice than in apoE-/- mice.
population_specificity: C57BL/6J (Bl6) and apolipoprotein E-deficient (apoE-/-) mice.
effective_dosage: Not specified (diets were administered ad libitum).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility of a high-protein diet (2.0 g/kg/day) in improving clinical outcomes, particularly muscle mass, in colorectal cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy.
results_summary: The study evaluates changes in muscle mass, physical function, and other clinical outcomes between high-protein and normal-protein diet groups, but specific results are not detailed in the abstract. Feasibility is assessed via muscle mass changes as a surrogate marker.
population_specificity: Newly diagnosed stage II-IV colorectal cancer patients scheduled for chemotherapy (n=40).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association between a high-protein diet (HPD) and handgrip strength (HGS) as well as survival in older adult outpatients with advanced gastrointestinal cancer.
results_summary: The study found no significant association between HPD and improved muscle function (HGS), but HPD was associated with higher overall survival (14.7 months vs. 7.3 months in the low-protein group).
population_specificity: Older adult outpatients (≥65 years) with advanced gastrointestinal cancer (stages III-IV).
effective_dosage: HPD defined as ≥1.5 g/kg/day, with an average intake of 2.2 ± 0.8 g/kg/day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining a high-protein whole food-based diet with concurrent aerobic and resistance exercise training improves strength, physical function, and body composition in older adults compared to exercise or nutrition alone.
results_summary: The study found that combining high-protein whole foods with exercise led to greater improvements in lower limb strength (leg press) compared to nutrition or exercise alone, though chest press strength and other measures (hand-grip, sit-to-stand) improved across all groups. Body fat increased in the nutrition-only group but not in the exercise or combined groups, while lean body mass changes did not differ between groups.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults (n = 56; age 69.3 ± 4.0 years; BMI 26.6 ± 3.7 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: Not specified (targeted increased protein-rich meals at breakfast, lunch, and dinner).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a carbohydrate-reduced high-protein (CRHP) diet reduces glycaemic variability (GV) in patients with type 2 diabetes (T2D) compared to a conventional diabetes (CD) diet.
results_summary: The CRHP diet significantly reduced all indices of glycaemic variability (by 36%-45%) and improved the diurnal glucose profile compared to the CD diet in T2D patients. The results were statistically significant (p < 0.001) across all measured GV metrics.
population_specificity: 16 metformin-treated T2D patients (median age 64.0 years, HbA1c 47 mmol/mol, T2D duration 5.5 years).
effective_dosage: Energy-matched CRHP diet (31% carbohydrates, 29% protein, 40% fat) vs. CD diet (54% carbohydrates, 16% protein, 30% fat).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a higher protein diet (2.50 g·kg⁻¹·day⁻¹) was more effective than a moderate protein diet (1.25 g·kg⁻¹·day⁻¹) in reducing markers of muscle damage and inflammation after strenuous exercise in older adults.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between the higher and moderate protein diets in attenuating muscle damage or inflammation markers post-exercise, except for a delayed peak in muscle soreness with the higher protein diet. Most inflammatory markers and muscle damage indicators remained unchanged by the intervention.
population_specificity: Older adults (10 males and 8 females, age 57 ± 4 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a high-protein diet alone or combined with power training on physical frailty in pre-frail and frail older adults.
results_summary: The study hypothesized that a high-protein diet from dairy products (1.5 g/kg/day) combined with power training could counteract frailty, potentially improving muscle power, physical function, and quality of life in older adults. Results were not explicitly stated in the abstract, but the study design suggests a focus on measurable outcomes like lower leg muscle power and frailty status.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling adults aged 80+ years who are pre-frail or frail.
effective_dosage: 1.5 g/kg/day of protein from dairy products.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of low-protein (10E%) and high-protein (30E%) hypocaloric diets in reducing liver fat and reversing NAFLD, and to explore the underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: The high-protein diet reduced intrahepatic lipid levels by 42.6%, suppressed fat uptake and lipid biosynthesis genes, and lowered inflammatory pathway activity, while the low-protein diet increased autophagy flux and serum FGF21 without significant liver fat reduction.
population_specificity: 19 participants with morbid obesity undergoing bariatric surgery.
effective_dosage: 30E% protein (high-protein group), 10E% protein (low-protein group), within a 1500-1600 kcal/day diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if combining whole-body electromyostimulation (WB-EMS) with a high-protein diet negatively impacts cardiac or renal function in sarcopenic obese seniors.
results_summary: The study found no short-term negative impact on renal function (eGFR) from high-protein intake, either alone or with WB-EMS. However, minor skeletal muscle damage and low-grade cardiac biomarker elevations were observed in the WB-EMS group, though without increased heart failure risk.
population_specificity: Sarcopenic obese men aged 70 years and older.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether ursolic acid (UA) combined with a high-protein diet and resistance training (RT) had synergistic effects on muscle strength and mass compared to RT alone in young men.
results_summary: Both the UA and placebo groups showed similar increases in muscle mass and strength, with no significant differences between them, indicating UA did not enhance the effects of RT and a high-protein diet. Body weight, BMI, and thigh circumference increased in both groups, but UA provided no additional benefits.
population_specificity: Young men undergoing resistance training and consuming a high-protein diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a high-protein diet versus a standard protein diet on appetite, anthropometry, and body composition in women with normal-weight obesity (NWO).
results_summary: The high-protein diet significantly improved body composition (increased lean body mass, reduced fat mass, body fat percentage, and waist circumference) compared to the standard protein diet, though weight and appetite remained unchanged in both groups.
population_specificity: Women with normal-weight obesity (NWO).
effective_dosage: 25% of total energy intake from protein (high-protein group) vs. 15% (standard protein group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chronic consumption of a high-protein diet (HPD) affects muscle protein synthesis (MPS) at rest and in response to acute resistance exercise (RE).
results_summary: The study found that 4 weeks of HPD reduced fat mass and increased skeletal muscle mass without affecting body weight. However, HPD did not alter resting MPS or the MPS response to acute RE.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats aged 10 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a high-protein diet combined with exercise could improve exercise tolerance, muscle and pulmonary functions, and quality of life in LOPD patients on long-term ERT.
results_summary: The study found that a high-protein diet combined with exercise significantly improved peak aerobic power, reduced muscle enzyme levels (LDH and CK), enhanced pulmonary function (FEV1), and improved quality of life (SF36 scores) compared to exercise alone. Compliance with the diet and exercise regimen was over 70%.
population_specificity: Late-onset Pompe disease (LOPD) patients (median age 49 ± 11 years) on long-term enzyme replacement therapy (median 6.0 ± 4.0 years).
effective_dosage: Diet composed of 25-30% protein, 30-35% carbohydrate, and 35-40% fat.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of high-protein diets (casein, whey, soy) on experimental colitis, microbiota composition, and colonic mucus layer structure and function.
results_summary: High-protein diets worsened acute DSS-induced colitis regardless of protein type, altered gut microbiota (increased mucin-degrading bacteria and sialidase), and reduced mucus layer thickness. Broad-spectrum antibiotics reversed these effects.
population_specificity: Female BALB/c mice
effective_dosage: Not specified (high-protein diets compared to standard diet)
interactions: Broad-spectrum antibiotics reversed high-protein diet effects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a carbohydrate-reduced high-protein (CRHP) diet versus a conventional diabetes (CD) diet on oxidative stress and inflammation in individuals with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: The CRHP diet increased RNA oxidation (8-oxoGuo) by 9.3% compared to the CD diet, but DNA oxidation (8-oxodG) and inflammatory markers did not differ significantly between the diets. The clinical implications of increased RNA oxidation with CRHP diets warrant further study.
population_specificity: Weight-stable individuals with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
effective_dosage: 30% energy from protein (CRHP) vs. 17% energy from protein (CD).
study_duration: 6 weeks per diet, with a crossover design totaling 12 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a high-protein diet (isolated whey protein) and omega-3 fatty acids on oxidative stress parameters in rats treated with Olanzapine.
results_summary: The study found that Olanzapine increased oxidative stress markers, but supplementation with a high-protein diet and omega-3 fatty acids mitigated these effects, with stronger benefits observed when used separately.
population_specificity: 8-week-old Wistar albino male rats weighing 200 ± 20 g.
interactions: Interaction with Olanzapine noted; no other interactions mentioned.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of a high-protein diet on cardiometabolic health, vascular function, and potential associations with plasma endocannabinoids in overweight participants.
results_summary: The high-protein diet did not significantly affect cardiometabolic health or vascular function compared to a moderate-protein diet, except for a higher heart rate in the HP group. OEA and PEA were positively associated with total cholesterol and LDL cholesterol, but no associations were found between vascular function markers and endocannabinoids.
population_specificity: Overweight participants (BMI 28.9 ± 4.0 kg/m², age 64.5 ± 5.9 years) who had previously undergone weight reduction.
effective_dosage: 25% protein, 45% carbohydrate, 30% fat (HP diet) vs. 15% protein, 55% carbohydrate, 30% fat (MP diet).
study_duration: 48 hours in a respiration chamber after ~34 months of body-weight maintenance post-weight loss.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of combining intragastric botulinum toxin type A injection (IG-BTxA) with a calorie-restricting high-protein diet on weight loss and comorbid conditions in obese patients.
results_summary: The study found that combining IG-BTxA with a high-protein diet resulted in significantly greater weight loss, better treatment adaptation, and positive behavioral changes in eating preferences compared to either intervention alone. Additionally, the combination led to reduced medication requirements for diabetes and hypertension.
population_specificity: Grade 2 obese patients (n=87) treated between January 2019 and August 2019.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of high-protein intake and arginine or ornithine supplementation on immune cell function in cats.
results_summary: The study found that arginine and ornithine supplementation had immunomodulating effects, with a quadratic effect on leukocyte proliferation and a linear decrease in phagocytic granulocytes. The highest responses were seen at moderate supplementation levels.
population_specificity: Ten healthy cats.
effective_dosage: Arginine supplementation (+50%, 75%, 100% of basal diet); ornithine supplementation (+100%, 150%, 200% of basal diet).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of a high-protein diet (HPD), with and without probiotics/prebiotics, on gut microbiota and wellness in older women.
results_summary: The study found that an HPD maintained wellness in healthy older women with minor microbiome perturbations, enhanced certain bacterial genera (e.g., Lactobacillus), and increased fat-free mass. Gastrointestinal distress slightly increased with inulin supplementation.
population_specificity: Healthy older women (mean age 73.7 ± 5.6 years; n=26).
effective_dosage: 1.5 to 2.2 g/kg/day protein, probiotic (1.54×10^9 Bifidobacterium bifidum HA-132, etc.), prebiotic (5.6 g inulin).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a high-protein diet could alter the lumbar vertebral marrow adipose tissue (MAT) gradient during bed rest.
results_summary: The study found that a high-protein diet did not change the lumbar vertebral fat fraction differences during bed rest, indicating no effect on the MAT gradient. The lack of mechanical stimulus (bed rest) also did not alter the MAT gradient.
population_specificity: 10 healthy men
study_duration: 21 days per bed rest campaign (2 campaigns total)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the effects of a high-protein diet on glycemic control, insulin resistance, and blood pressure in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: The study found that a high-protein diet did not significantly improve glycemic control or blood pressure but did lower LDL, TC, TG, and HOMA-IR levels in T2DM patients. The difference in insulin resistance between the high-protein diet and control groups was statistically significant.
population_specificity: 1,138 patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to predict changes in blood ammonia levels due to altered dietary protein intake, liver disease, or urea cycle dysfunction.
results_summary: Increasing dietary protein by 72% raised blood ammonia levels by 59%. Liver cirrhosis and CPS1 gene mutations further elevated ammonia levels, with differentiated SH-SY5Y cells showing reduced viability under high ammonia conditions.
population_specificity: Liver disease patients and heterozygous carriers of CPS1 loss-of-function alleles.
effective_dosage: Not specified (simulated dietary protein intake increase of 72%).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a casein- and pea protein-enriched high-protein diet (HPD) could counteract arsenic-induced reproductive toxicity in female rats.
results_summary: The HPD largely counteracted arsenic-induced disruptions in estrus cycles, uterine oxidative stress, and apoptosis, maintaining reproductive functions close to control levels.
population_specificity: Cyclic female rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if an 8-week low-carbohydrate/high-protein (LC/HP) dietary intervention improves metabolic function, body composition, gut microbiome composition, and quality of life in individuals with chronic spinal cord injury (SCI).
results_summary: The abstract does not report specific results but outlines the study's intent to assess improvements in glucose tolerance, insulin sensitivity, β-cell function, body composition, gut microbiome, and quality of life after the LC/HP intervention.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic traumatic SCI (3+ years post-injury, C5-L2, ASIA impairment scale A-D, aged 18-65) and insulin resistance, impaired glucose tolerance, or untreated type 2 diabetes.
effective_dosage: ~30% total energy as protein (1.6 g/kg per day), carbohydrate-to-protein ratio <1.5, fat intake ~30% of total energy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a high-protein diet (HPD) could accelerate nephropathy in db/db mice and evaluate its usefulness as a model for faster drug efficacy studies.
results_summary: HPD significantly increased renal injury markers, activated the Renin-angiotensin system, and induced hyperfiltration in db/db mice. The HPD db/db model was useful for rapid drug evaluation, as demonstrated by dapagliflozin's effects on hyperfiltration.
population_specificity: Diabetic (C57BLKS-Leprdb/db) and non-diabetic (C57BLKS-Leprdb/+) mice.
effective_dosage: 60 kcal% protein (HPD) vs. 22 kcal% protein (control diet).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a carbohydrate-reduced high-protein (CRHP) diet versus a conventional diabetes (CD) diet on glycaemic control and cardiovascular risk markers in individuals with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The CRHP diet significantly reduced HbA1c, fasting plasma glucose, postprandial glucose, hepatic fat content, and pancreatic fat content compared to the CD diet, with no significant differences in 24-hour blood pressure or other fat depots.
population_specificity: Men and women with type 2 diabetes (HbA1c 6.5-11%, age >18 years, eGFR >30 ml/min/1.73 m²).
effective_dosage: CRHP diet: 30% carbohydrate, 30% protein, 40% fat (by energy percentage).
study_duration: 6 weeks per diet (crossover design, total 12 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether consuming twice the recommended daily allowance (RDA) of protein affects the expression of amino acid transporters, sensors, and mTORC1 activity in older men.
results_summary: Consuming twice the RDA of protein reduced LAT1 expression but did not alter mTORC1 activity or plasma leucine levels. Total RPS6 increased, suggesting potential improvements in muscular translational capacity.
population_specificity: Older men aged 70-81 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a high-protein diet combined with β-cryptoxanthin supplementation on metabolic factors, inflammatory markers, and body composition in obese and overweight individuals with NAFLD.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results, as the study is described as a planned randomized controlled trial.
population_specificity: Obese and overweight adults (BMI 25-40 kg/m²), aged 18-60 years, of both genders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of a high-protein diet on weight loss among postpartum women.
results_summary: The study found that the high-protein diet group (IG) experienced greater weight loss compared to the control group (CG), with protein intake and lower carbohydrate intake associated with improved body weight loss. Lipid intake was negatively associated with body weight, while carbohydrate intake was positively associated with body weight over time.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese postpartum women.
effective_dosage: Approximately 25 g of protein per day from 125 g of sardine per week.
study_duration: Recruitment occurred from February 2009 to December 2011; exact intervention duration not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of high-protein (HPD) and high-protein/glucose-free (GFD) diets on muscle performance, metabolic control, and liver health in a mouse model of Glycogen Storage Disease Type III (GSDIII).
results_summary: The GFD diet improved muscle performance and reduced muscle glycogen content and fiber vacuolization, even in aged mice, while HPD showed limited benefits only in younger mice. GFD also reduced hepatomegaly by 20% and improved metabolic control without worsening serum parameters over eight months.
population_specificity: Mouse model of Glycogen Storage Disease Type III (GSDIII).
study_duration: 9 months (from 1 month to 10 months of age).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a long-term high-protein diet (34.3% protein) on metabolic outcomes in high-sucrose-fed rats, focusing on weight loss, glucose tolerance, insulin resistance, and liver function.
results_summary: The high-protein diet reversed weight gain and adipose tissue accumulation, restored lipolytic response, improved glucolipid homeostasis, and reversed hepatic steatosis. Simple withdrawal from high-sucrose consumption also improved metabolic outcomes but did not affect body weight.
population_specificity: Weaned male Wistar rats with induced metabolic syndrome phenotype.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the systemic effects of a high-protein diet (HPD) on inflammation in different tissues (skin and colon) using mouse models.
results_summary: HPD reduced TPA-induced skin inflammation markers (hyperplasia, cell proliferation, COX-2 expression) but increased DSS-induced colon inflammation markers (mucosal hyperplasia, colonocyte proliferation, COX-2 expression, plasma nitric oxide). This suggests HPD has tissue-specific effects on inflammation.
population_specificity: ICR mice (animal model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the impact of an early high-protein diet on neurofunctional recovery, cerebral infarct areas, and oxidative stress in rats with ischemic stroke.
results_summary: The high-protein diet group showed faster weight gain, lower neurological impairment scores, improved motor coordination and balance, smaller cerebral infarct areas, increased SOD expression, and reduced MDA and iNOS expressions compared to the standard-protein diet group. No significant differences were observed between sham groups.
population_specificity: Adult male Sprague Dawley rats (7-8 months old, 250-280 g) with induced ischemic stroke.
study_duration: Intervention started on the first day post-surgery; duration not explicitly stated.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of an isocaloric high-protein diet versus combination exercise training on muscle adaptations in individuals with long-standing spinal cord injury.
results_summary: The high-protein diet did not significantly improve muscle fiber distribution, cross-sectional area, or lean thigh mass compared to the combination exercise regimen, which showed favorable changes in both paralytic and nonparalytic muscles. The study concluded that dietary protein alone may not be sufficient to counteract muscle atrophy in this population.
population_specificity: Individuals with long-standing spinal cord injury (C5-T12 levels, 21.8 ± 6.3 years post-injury).
effective_dosage: Protein comprised 30% of total energy intake (isocaloric diet).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a high-protein diet combined with resistance training could accelerate the resolution of inflammation in hospitalized elderly patients with systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS).
results_summary: The intervention group showed an earlier decrease in suPAR levels during hospitalization compared to the control group, but no significant effects were observed for other inflammatory biomarkers. Nutritional support during hospitalization was associated with accelerated recovery, while post-discharge nutrition and resistance training did not significantly affect inflammation.
population_specificity: Acutely admitted elderly patients aged >65 years with SIRS.
effective_dosage: 1.7 g/kg per day during hospitalization, and daily protein supplement (18.8 g) post-discharge.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the laxative and immune-regulating effects of Xiao'er Qixingcha (EXQ) on constipation in mice induced by a high-heat and high-protein diet (HHPD).
results_summary: EXQ improved fecal output, reduced inflammatory markers (TNF-α, IL-10, LPS), and protected colonic mucosal integrity in constipated mice. The effects were dose-dependent and consistent across two different constipation models.
population_specificity: Mice (pediatric constipation models induced by HHPD or HHPD + atropine).
effective_dosage: 0.75, 1.5, and 3 g/kg of EXQ administered daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a high-protein diet and/or resistance exercise could preserve fat-free mass (FFM) during weight loss in overweight and obese older adults.
results_summary: The study found that neither a high-protein diet nor resistance exercise alone significantly affected changes in FFM, but the combination of both significantly increased FFM (+0.6 kg). No significant interaction between the high-protein diet and exercise was observed for FFM changes.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese adults aged 55-80 years.
effective_dosage: High-protein diet (1.3 g/kg body weight) vs. normal protein diet (0.8 g/kg body weight).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of a high-protein diet on colonic mucosal inflammation and recovery in DSS-treated mice.
results_summary: The high-protein diet showed deleterious effects during the post-induction phase of colitis, including higher inflammation intensity and mortality, but was associated with enhanced colonic epithelium restoration in surviving animals.
population_specificity: DSS-treated mice (animal model of colitis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a high-protein diet (>3 g/kg/d) combined with heavy resistance training affects body composition, performance, and health in trained individuals.
results_summary: The high-protein group showed greater reductions in fat mass and body fat percentage compared to the normal-protein group, though both groups improved strength similarly. No adverse effects on blood parameters were observed.
population_specificity: 48 healthy resistance-trained men and women (mean age ~23-25 years, training experience 2.4-4.9 years).
effective_dosage: High-protein group: 3.4 g/kg/d; normal-protein group: 2.3 g/kg/d.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a high-protein diet (>3 g/kg/day) affects clinical health markers, performance, and body composition in resistance-trained young men.
results_summary: The study found no significant changes in body composition, health markers (blood lipids, renal, hepatic function), or performance between the high-protein and normal diet groups, with no reported side effects.
population_specificity: 12 healthy, resistance-trained young men (mean age 25.9 ± 3.7 years, 7.6 ± 3.6 years of training experience).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the short-term and long-term effects of a maternal high-protein diet during pregnancy or lactation on offspring growth and hepatic gene expression in mice.
results_summary: Maternal high-protein diet during lactation (CHP) caused sustained growth retardation in offspring but reduced hepatic gene effects in adults, while prenatal high-protein diet (HPC) did not affect growth but increased hepatic gene effects in adults. Only a small subset of genes was consistently affected in both weanlings and adults.
population_specificity: Mouse offspring (male) from dams fed high-protein or control diets during pregnancy or lactation.
study_duration: Evaluated at weaning and 150 days after birth.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of prolonged adaptation to low versus high dietary protein intake on whole-body protein turnover and basal muscle protein synthesis rates.
results_summary: After 12 weeks, the high-protein diet resulted in a more negative whole-body protein balance and higher protein breakdown, synthesis, and phenylalanine hydroxylation rates compared to the low-protein diet, but basal muscle protein synthesis rates remained similar between groups.
population_specificity: 40 subjects (subgroup of 7 men and 8 women, BMI 22.8±2.3 kg/m², age 24.3±4.9 y).
effective_dosage: High protein (2.4 g/kg/d) vs. low protein (0.4 g/kg/d).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a high-protein, low-calorie diet combined with multi-ingredient supplements (thermogenic, CLA, protein gel, multi-vitamin) improved weight loss and body composition compared to diet alone or placebo supplements in young women.
results_summary: The study found that the high-protein diet with supplements (SUP) led to greater weight loss, total fat loss, and subcutaneous fat loss compared to the diet with placebo (PLA) or no dietary change (CON). SUP also significantly reduced skinfold thickness at five sites, indicating localized fat loss.
population_specificity: 37 recreationally-trained young women (age 27.1 ± 4.2 years, BMI 25.1 ± 3.4).
effective_dosage: Not specified (abstract does not detail supplement dosages).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of a low carbohydrate diet compared to a Western diet on prostate cancer tumor growth and steroid regulation in mice.
results_summary: The study found that a low carbohydrate diet significantly reduced tumor growth rate in castrated mice but not in intact mice. It also altered steroid profiles and cholesterol levels, with lower DHT concentrations in the low carb group.
population_specificity: Mice bearing LNCaP xenograft tumors (intact and castrated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the metabolic differences and weight loss effects of a high-protein, low-carbohydrate diet (HPLC) compared to a moderate-protein, moderate-carbohydrate diet (MPMC) in rats.
results_summary: The HPLC diet induced weight loss, reduced adipose weight and plasma triglycerides, and altered plasma and urinary metabolite profiles, including changes in TCA cycle intermediates and energy metabolism markers. Biomarker screening identified distinct metabolic profiles between the HPLC and MPMC groups.
population_specificity: Rats (obese population model)
effective_dosage: 45% protein, 30% carbohydrate (HPLC diet); 20% protein, 56% carbohydrate (MPMC diet)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a high-protein diet, with or without resveratrol supplementation, on immune cell changes and inflammation recovery in rats exposed to abdominal irradiation.
results_summary: A high-protein diet increased lymphocyte percentage and IgM concentration while decreasing neutrophil percentage and modulating lipid profiles. Resveratrol supplementation further reduced proinflammatory cytokine production and enhanced IgM levels and splenocyte proliferation.
population_specificity: Female Wistar rats exposed to 17.5 Gy abdominal irradiation.
effective_dosage: 30% high-protein diet; resveratrol dosage not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of a short-term low-calorie, high-protein, high-fiber diet on hepatic steatosis using non-invasive elastography.
results_summary: The study found a significant 14.0% reduction in hepatic fat content (CAP) after 14 days, alongside reductions in body weight (4.6%), liver stiffness, γ-GT activities, and serum lipid concentrations. These results suggest rapid improvements in hepatic lipid turnover and metabolic parameters.
population_specificity: 60 patients with hepatic steatosis (median age 56 years, 51.7% women, median BMI 31.9 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a high-protein diet could improve acute inflammatory responses and lipid metabolism in rats after experimental abdominal radiation treatment.
results_summary: The high-protein diet significantly reduced triglyceride levels, proinflammatory cytokines, and 8-OHdG, while improving white blood cell counts and lipid profiles. It also decreased regulatory T cells and increased lymphocyte percentages compared to the control diet.
population_specificity: Rats exposed to abdominal radiation treatment (17.5 Gy).

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to highlight the severity of motor fluctuations in Parkinson's disease (PD) and the critical need for prompt dopaminergic therapy reinstatement in cases of missed medication doses.
results_summary: The study reported a case of a PD patient who fell into a coma after missing one or two doses of medication, with rapid recovery upon reintroduction of dopaminergic therapy. It emphasizes the dramatic presentation of motor fluctuations in PD and the urgency of treatment resumption.
population_specificity: A single patient with longstanding Parkinson's disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a high-protein diet on hepatic steatosis and inflammation in hyperlipidaemic mice.
results_summary: The high-protein diet reduced hepatic fat and cholesterol concentrations by 40-55%, mildly attenuated hepatic inflammation, decreased VLDL-associated plasma cholesterol by 20-40%, but increased plasma TAG concentrations 3-4-fold. The diet also appeared to enhance mitochondrial metabolism.
population_specificity: Hyperlipidaemic male and female APOE2 knock-in (APOE2ki) mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a very high protein diet (4.4 g/kg/d) on body composition in resistance-trained individuals.
results_summary: The high-protein group consumed significantly more protein and calories but showed no significant changes in body weight, fat mass, fat-free mass, or percent body fat compared to the control group. The study concluded that a hypercaloric high-protein diet does not increase body fat in resistance-trained individuals.
population_specificity: Thirty healthy resistance-trained men and women (mean age 24.1 ± 5.6 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a high-protein diet helps maintain reduced blood pressure after initial weight loss compared to a lower-protein diet.
results_summary: The study found that systolic blood pressure increased less in the high-protein group (2.2 mm Hg less than the control group), with a more pronounced effect in (pre)hypertensive subjects (-4.2 mm Hg). The effect was partly mediated by body weight.
population_specificity: 420 overweight adults (42±6 years) with a BMI of 30.3±4.3 kg/m² after weight loss, including 28 subjects using antihypertensive agents.
effective_dosage: High-protein diet (23-28 en% protein) vs. lower-protein control diet (10-15 en% protein).
study_duration: 26 weeks of weight maintenance after an 8-week weight-loss period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a high-protein diet (30% energy intake) improves cardiac function and survival in rats with pressure overload-induced heart failure compared to a standard protein diet (18% energy intake).
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in cardiac hypertrophy, contractile dysfunction, ventricular dilation, or mitochondrial oxidative capacity between the high-protein and standard-protein diets. However, the high-protein diet significantly decreased survival in rats with advanced heart failure.
population_specificity: Rats with pressure overload-induced heart failure (transverse aortic constriction model).
effective_dosage: 30% of energy intake from protein (high-protein diet) vs. 18% (standard diet).
study_duration: 14 weeks (initial assessment) and 22 weeks (advanced heart failure assessment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a high-protein diet could reduce chemotherapy toxicities and improve quality of life in cancer patients.
results_summary: The study found insufficient evidence to conclusively determine the efficacy of a high-protein diet, but suggested it may complement conventional cancer therapy by potentially reducing chemotherapy toxicities. No significant adverse effects were reported, but more research is needed.
population_specificity: Cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of lifestyle and behavioral interventions, including exercise and dietary regimens, on improving anthropometric indices and body composition in individuals with spinal cord injury (SCI).
results_summary: Exercise-based interventions, alone or combined with functional electrical stimulation (FES) or dietary regimens, showed promise in improving body composition and anthropometric indices in individuals with SCI, though the findings may not apply to those with high SCI lesions.
population_specificity: Individuals with spinal cord injury (SCI)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the physiological mechanisms by which a high-protein diet (HPD) reduces body weight in diet-induced obese rats switched from a Western-type diet.
results_summary: Switching obese rats from a Western-type diet to HPD reduced food intake by 30% initially and 9% by day 9, decreased body weight, and led to a 72% greater fat mass loss compared to controls, while lean mass remained unchanged. HPD also improved glucose tolerance and increased levels of satiety hormones like pancreatic polypeptide and peptide YY.
population_specificity: Male diet-induced obese rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the role of macronutrient composition, specifically a high-protein diet, in weight loss and the potential influence of genetic predisposition among Greek adults.
results_summary: The study compared a hypocaloric, high-protein diet with a high-carbohydrate, hypocaloric diet over 3 months, measuring weight and BMI changes, but specific results regarding the high-protein diet's effectiveness were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Greek adults (202 participants, 94 on high-protein diet).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining moderate to high-intensity resistance training with a high-protein diet (steamed chicken breast) could improve muscle mass, strength, and quality while mitigating resistance training-induced arterial stiffness in elderly women.
results_summary: The study found that the combination of resistance training and high-protein intake significantly improved muscle mass, strength, and quality while preventing the increase in arterial stiffness observed with resistance training alone. The high-protein diet effectively counteracted the negative vascular effects of resistance training.
population_specificity: Elderly women (mean age 67.2 ± 5.3 years).
effective_dosage: Steamed chicken breast as a high-protein diet, in addition to the daily diet (exact protein amount not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a carbohydrate-reduced high-protein (CRHP) diet improves glucometabolic control in individuals with type 2 diabetes compared to a conventional diabetes diet over 12 months.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results but hypothesizes that a CRHP diet may improve glycaemic control, with long-term adherence facilitated by meal kits and nutrition education.
population_specificity: 100 individuals with type 2 diabetes and BMI >25 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the limitations of using serum creatinine for GFR estimation, including the influence of a high-protein diet on creatinine levels.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that serum creatinine, used for GFR estimation, is influenced by factors like high-protein diets, leading to potential inaccuracies in eGFRcr values. It suggests alternative methods (eGFRcys or eGFRcr-cys) for more precise GFR estimation.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD), particularly those with diabetes.
interactions: Medications affecting tubular creatinine excretion (H2 blockers, trimethoprim, fenofibrate, ritonavir, and other HIV drugs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a High-Protein Diet (HPD) and a High-Protein and High Dietary Fiber Diet (HPD+HDF) with a Calorie Restricted Diet (CRD) on body composition, insulin resistance, and oxidative stress in overweight/obese PCOS patients.
results_summary: The study found that HPD and HPD+HDF were effective in reducing body weight by over 5% in 8 weeks, retaining lean body mass better than CRD, and significantly improving oxidative stress damage and insulin resistance.
population_specificity: Overweight/obese women with Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether a high-protein, low-glycemic-load diet could prevent weight gain in kidney transplant patients compared to a conventional diet.
results_summary: The high-protein diet did not significantly prevent weight gain, with both groups showing similar increases in body weight (5.75% mean increment). The intervention was safe but ineffective for weight management, though it improved protein intake and reduced glycemic load without adverse effects on kidney function.
population_specificity: Kidney transplant patients (n=120).
effective_dosage: High-protein group: 1.3-1.4 g/kg/day; control group: 0.8-1.0 g/kg/day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore how high-protein diets, among other dietary patterns, interact with the gut microbiota to influence sports performance and health outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that high-protein diets, along with other dietary patterns, can improve vascular function, reduce illness risk, promote recovery, and aid in weight control, potentially enhancing sports performance through gut microbiota interactions.
population_specificity: Athletes and individuals focused on sports performance.

study_goal: The researchers sought to identify specific metabolites mediating the effects of a high-protein diet combined with neuromuscular electrical stimulation on muscle atrophy in patients after aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage.
results_summary: The study identified 18 unique metabolites differentiating standard care from the high-protein diet + NMES group, with 9 metabolites positively correlating with protein intake. N-acetylleucine and quinolinate were significantly associated with preserved muscle volume in temporalis and quadriceps.
population_specificity: Patients recovering from aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage (N=24).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of a normocaloric, hyperproteic oral nutritional supplement on body composition in patients after sleeve gastrectomy compared to a standard progression diet.
results_summary: The study found that the hyperproteic supplement slowed muscle mass loss and increased fat mass loss without affecting total weight loss compared to the standard diet.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent sleeve gastrectomy (mean age 47.35 years, 75% women, average presurgical BMI 45.98 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: 820 kcal, 65.5 g protein daily for the intervention group; 220 kcal, 11.5 g protein daily for the control group.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a high-protein diet combined with physical exercise on hepatic and cerebral hemodynamics, cognitive function, nutritional status, and quality of life in patients with cirrhosis.
results_summary: The study found that the intervention group (diet + exercise) showed improved cerebral hemodynamics, cognitive function, nutritional status, and quality of life, along with a significant reduction in hepatic venous pressure gradient (HVPG). The control group (diet alone) did not show significant changes in these parameters.
population_specificity: Patients with cirrhosis, mainly Child-Pugh A (88.9%), median MELD score of 8, mean age 53±8 years.
effective_dosage: Not specified (high-protein diet details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of a high-energy high-protein diet supplemented with nocturnal nasogastric feeding (NGF) on muscle strength and nutritional parameters in severely malnourished cirrhosis patients awaiting liver transplant.
results_summary: The study found that NGF significantly improved handgrip strength (20% increase from baseline), mid-upper-arm circumference, triceps skinfold, immune function, and daily energy and protein intake. Posttransplant clinical outcomes were similar between groups.
population_specificity: 55 patients with severe malnutrition and low handgrip strength (HGS) awaiting liver transplant (median age 58.5 years, median MELD score 24, 58% male).
effective_dosage: Supplemental nocturnal NGF increased daily protein intake by 51 g (95% CI: 32-71).
study_duration: Median duration of NGF was 63.0 days (34.5-127).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the potential role of a high-protein diet in managing sarcopenic obesity in the elderly population.
results_summary: The study found that a combined approach of hypocaloric diet and high protein intake may be effective in managing both obesity and sarcopenia in older individuals. Appropriate dietary factors, including protein intake, were linked to improved sarcopenic obesity-related parameters.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals with sarcopenic obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a high-protein diet combined with leg-focused high-weight resistance training could improve exercise capacity, cardiac function, muscle strength, and quality of life in pediatric Fontan patients.
results_summary: The study found that the intervention significantly improved peak oxygen uptake, stroke volume, muscle strength, and certain domains of quality of life, with no adverse effects reported.
population_specificity: Pediatric Fontan patients (median age 12.9 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of a Mediterranean diet on body composition, nutritional status, and inflammatory markers in colorectal cancer patients with cachexia.
results_summary: The Mediterranean diet group showed significant improvements in weight, nutritional status, inflammatory markers, and quality of life compared to the control group receiving nutritional counseling. The diet appeared effective in managing cachexia-related outcomes.
population_specificity: 46 patients with colorectal cancer-induced cachexia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the prevalence and severity of functional and nutritional sequelae after pancreatic surgery and the role of a high-calorie, high-protein diet in managing these deficiencies.
results_summary: The study found that pancreatic surgery often leads to exocrine and endocrine pancreatic insufficiency, digestive disorders, and nutritional deficiencies. Nutritional management, including a high-calorie, high-protein diet with vitamin supplementation, was recommended to address these issues.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent pancreatic surgery for cancerous or pre-cancerous lesions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review interventions for obesity in Saudi Arabia, including the role of high-protein diets among other dietary approaches.
results_summary: The abstract mentions that high-protein diets are one of several dietary interventions with potential impact on weight loss, but no specific results for high-protein diets are detailed.
population_specificity: General population in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, particularly those affected by obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current literature on how nutrition, including high-protein diets, contributes to liver disease and to provide recommendations for screening and dietary interventions.
results_summary: The study found that a high-protein diet (1.2-1.5 g/kg/day) can improve nutritional status in patients with cirrhosis and sarcopenia, alongside a Mediterranean diet and increased physical activity. Routine screening for malnutrition, obesity, and sarcopenia is critical for identifying at-risk patients.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic liver disease, particularly those with cirrhosis and sarcopenia or metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify dietary interventions, including high-protein diets, that could prevent secondary health conditions in individuals with spinal cord injury.
results_summary: The study identified high-protein diets as one of the most promising dietary strategies for preventing secondary health conditions in individuals with spinal cord injury, based on a systematic review of interventional and observational studies.
population_specificity: Adult individuals with spinal cord injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of orlistat, alongside a high-protein diet and other treatments, in managing chylous ascites in a liver cirrhosis patient.
results_summary: The study found that orlistat, combined with dietary modifications (including a high-protein diet), led to a significant reduction in ascites volume and chylous content, with triglyceride levels dropping from 3.5 mmol/L to 0.7 mmol/L.
population_specificity: A 59-year-old male with decompensated liver disease and chylous ascites.
effective_dosage: Not specified for the high-protein diet; orlistat dosage not detailed.
study_duration: Two weeks (duration of dietary and orlistat intervention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a high-protein diet (HPD), a high-protein and high-dietary fiber diet (HPHFD), and a calorie-restricted diet (CRD) on metabolic health and gut microbiota in overweight/obese PCOS patients.
results_summary: The study compared body weight, body fat percentage, lean body mass, blood lipids, inflammation, glucose tolerance, blood pressure, and gut microbiota compositions across the three diet groups, but specific results for the high-protein diet were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Overweight/obese patients with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).
effective_dosage: 1.5-2.0 g/kg protein per day for the HPD group.

study_goal: To determine if a high-protein, mycoprotein-rich vegan diet supports resistance training-induced muscle remodeling as effectively as an isonitrogenous omnivorous diet.
results_summary: Both omnivorous and vegan diets supported similar daily muscle protein synthesis (MyoPS) rates and skeletal muscle adaptive responses during prolonged resistance training, regardless of protein source.
population_specificity: 16 healthy young adults (8 male, 8 female; age 23 ± 1 years; BMI 23 ± 1 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine whether a high-protein diet modifies the association between genetically determined gut microbial abundance and changes in adiposity and body composition in overweight or obese individuals.
results_summary: The study found that a higher genetically determined relative abundance of gut microbial taxa was associated with greater reductions in fat mass and body fat percentage, but these associations were attenuated in the high-protein diet group compared to the average-protein diet group.
population_specificity: 692 participants with overweight or obesity from the POUNDS Lost trial.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of therapeutic interventions, including high-protein diets, in managing diabetic nephropathy by reducing glomerular hyperfiltration and proteinuria.
results_summary: The study suggests that inhibiting the renin-angiotensin axis or sodium-glucose co-transport may allow for a high-protein diet, which could benefit sarcopenic diabetic patients, though substantial renal injury may occur even without proteinuria.
population_specificity: Diabetic patients, particularly those with or at risk of nephropathy and sarcopenia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the safety and effectiveness of a high-protein diet (HP) versus a normal protein diet (NP) and a nutritional meal replacement (MR) during alternate-day fasting for weight loss in Chinese adults.
results_summary: The high-protein diet group (HP) lost 2.16 kg, comparable to the NP (2.63 kg) and MR (2.94 kg) groups, with no significant differences. Adverse events included dizziness, heart palpitations, and fatigue, but the diet was generally well-tolerated.
population_specificity: Chinese adults without BMI restrictions (N=60).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a high-protein diet as part of conservative management for chyle leaks after axillary node clearance in breast cancer patients.
results_summary: The study found that a high-protein diet, combined with other nutritional interventions, successfully managed chyle leaks without adverse effects on wound healing or delays in adjuvant treatment. All leaks resolved conservatively within 11-29 days.
population_specificity: Breast cancer patients who underwent axillary node clearance and developed chyle leaks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of moderate-protein and high-protein diets containing different amounts of unprocessed beef on weight maintenance, body composition, and cardiometabolic risk factors after rapid weight loss.
results_summary: Both diets led to similar outcomes in weight maintenance, fat mass reduction, lean mass increase, and resting energy expenditure, with no significant differences between groups. Cardiometabolic risk factors showed no differential effects between the diets, generally reverting to baseline during maintenance despite mild further weight loss.
population_specificity: 108 adults (45 males, 63 females) with BMI 28-40 kg/m², who lost ≥8% body weight during an initial 8-week rapid weight loss phase.
effective_dosage: 25 g beef/day (moderate-protein diet) vs. 150 g beef/day (high-protein diet).
study_duration: 12-week weight maintenance phase following an 8-week rapid weight loss period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal protein intake for patients with digestive cancers to achieve nutritional and clinical benefits.
results_summary: High-protein diets (1-1.5 g/kg body weight/day) were found to maintain adequate nutritional status and provide clinical benefits, particularly in malnourished or older patients with digestive cancers. Animal proteins were recommended as the majority of intake, but no specific amino acids were strongly endorsed for enhancing anabolic or immune-modulating effects.
population_specificity: Patients with digestive cancers, particularly those at risk of or already malnourished, and older patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the bidirectional relationship between periodontal diseases and chronic kidney disease (CKD), focusing on nutritional and inflammatory mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that CKD and periodontal diseases negatively influence each other through malnutrition, vitamin dysregulation, oxidative stress, and low-grade inflammation, necessitating multidisciplinary management.
population_specificity: Adult hemodialysis (HD) patients with CKD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of acute high-protein or high-carbohydrate diets on endurance performance and gut microbial changes in elite athletes.
results_summary: The study found that high-carbohydrate diets improved time-trial performance by 6.5%, but the abstract does not specify the performance outcomes for the high-protein diet. Gut microbial community changes were also explored, but detailed results for the high-protein diet are not provided.
population_specificity: Highly trained endurance runners

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of weight loss induced by a carbohydrate-restricted high-protein diet on health-related quality of life and cognition in adults with type 2 diabetes and overweight/obesity.
results_summary: Both diets led to similar weight loss and improved physical health, but the high-protein diet showed a non-significant trend toward better mental health. However, it worsened psychomotor speed compared to the control diet, while global cognition, attention, and verbal memory remained unaffected.
population_specificity: Adults with type 2 diabetes and overweight/obesity (mean HbA1c 7.5%, BMI 34.5 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether combining cycle ergometry with a high-protein diet improved clinical outcomes in critically ill patients compared to conventional physiotherapy with standard enteral nutrition.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant differences in length of ventilation, ICU mortality, ICU stay, hospital stay, or re-intubation rates between the groups receiving cycle ergometry with standard or protein-enriched enteral nutrition and the control group.
population_specificity: Critically ill patients in the ICU.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine how changes in physical activity influenced weight loss and body composition in response to different weight-loss diets, including high-protein diets.
results_summary: Increased physical activity was associated with greater weight loss and reduced waist circumference, with stronger effects observed in high-fat or average-protein diets compared to low-fat or high-protein diets. Participants with sustained physical activity maintained weight loss over 24 months.
population_specificity: 535 participants with overweight/obesity

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of food, beverages, and dietary supplements, including high-protein diets, on the pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of drugs used by Parkinson's disease patients.
results_summary: The study found that a high-protein diet negatively affects levodopa pharmacokinetics and effectiveness, contrasting with potential benefits from low-fat and protein redistribution diets.
population_specificity: Parkinson's disease patients
interactions: High-protein diet negatively interacts with levodopa; ferrous sulfate supplements also adversely affect levodopa.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a modified ERAS protocol for ambulatory pelvic organ prolapse surgery, focusing on postoperative complications and readmissions.
results_summary: The study found that the site-specific ERAS protocol was effective for standardized care, with low complication rates (4.4%) and minimal unplanned admissions (0.4%). Complication rates decreased further with experience and familiarity with the protocol.
population_specificity: Women undergoing ambulatory pelvic organ prolapse surgery at the Townsville Day Surgery between January 2008 and June 2019.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical effects of immunomodulating (IM) plus high-protein (HP) supplements versus pure HP supplements during the preoperative period in patients undergoing major abdominal surgery.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between IM+HP and HP supplements in terms of postoperative complications, length of hospital stay, readmission rates, or gastrointestinal function. Both groups showed comparable outcomes, suggesting no added benefit from IM supplements.
population_specificity: Well-nourished patients (130 female, 169 male; mean age 60.8 years) undergoing major abdominal surgery at two surgical centers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of creatine monohydrate supplementation combined with a high-protein diet and cluster-set resistance training on lower-limb fat-free mass and muscular strength.
results_summary: The study found that creatine monohydrate supplementation, when combined with a high-protein diet and cluster-set resistance training, improved lower-limb fat-free mass and muscular strength in resistance-trained men.
population_specificity: Resistance-trained men (>2 years of training experience, aged 26.6 ± 8.1 years, height 176.3 ± 6.8 cm, weight 75.6 ± 8.9 kg).

study_goal: The abstract does not specify a study goal focused on High-Protein Diet; it broadly discusses risk factors for osteoporosis, including protein intake.
results_summary: The abstract mentions that a high-protein diet is a potentially modifiable risk factor for osteoporosis but does not provide specific study results on its effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of osteoporosis patients).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of six months of soy-enriched high protein snack replacement on appetite, body composition, and dietary intake in women with normal-weight obesity (NWO).
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results, but the study focused on evaluating the effects of soy-enriched high protein snacks on appetite, body composition, and dietary intake in women with NWO.
population_specificity: Women with normal-weight obesity (NWO), aged 24 ± 3 years, BMI 22.7 ± 2.3 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of a balanced Mediterranean diet with a low-carbohydrate diet on weight loss and glucose homeostasis in morbidly obese individuals at high risk for diabetes.
results_summary: The low-carbohydrate diet resulted in 58% greater weight loss than the Mediterranean diet, though both diets similarly improved insulin resistance, fasting hyperinsulinemia, insulin clearance, and β-cell glucose sensitivity without affecting fasting plasma glucose or glucose tolerance.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese individuals at high risk for diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Herbalife high-protein meal replacement products in reducing body weight and related metrics.
results_summary: Participants consuming Herbalife HP products showed significant reductions in body weight, BMI, and fat mass compared to controls. Safety outcomes indicated no major risks, though blood urea nitrogen levels increased more in the treatment group.
population_specificity: 934 participants (463 in treatment, 471 in control groups) from nine randomized controlled trials.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the short-term effects of a hypocaloric Mediterranean diet and two high-protein diets (with and without whey supplementation) on body composition, lipid profile, and inflammation/muscle-damage markers in overweight, sedentary young individuals.
results_summary: The high-protein diets (with and without whey) led to less favorable outcomes compared to the Mediterranean diet, including increased subclinical inflammation and muscle-damage markers, and no significant improvement in lipid profile. Body and fat mass reductions were smaller in the high-protein groups than in the Mediterranean diet group.
population_specificity: Overweight, sedentary young adults (mean age 22.8 ± 4.8 years; body mass 85.5 ± 10.2 kg; body fat percentage 34.3% ± 8.1%).
effective_dosage: Not specified (hypocaloric -700 kcal/day for all diets).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical effects of a high-protein diet (25% daily calorie intake from protein) compared to a regular-protein diet (15% daily calorie intake from protein) on body composition, muscle mass, physical endurance, and inflammatory biomarkers in middle-aged and older adults.
results_summary: The high-protein group showed significant improvement in 6-minute walking distance and a marginal reduction in intramuscular adiposity compared to the regular-protein group, but also exhibited increased high-sensitivity C-reactive protein, indicating higher inflammation. Both groups experienced reductions in body weight, BMI, total body fat percentage, and handgrip strength, with no significant change in relative appendicular muscle mass.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling middle-aged and older adults (mean age: 53.7 ± 8.3 years, 53.8% male).
effective_dosage: 25% of daily calories from protein (high-protein group) vs. 15% (regular-protein group), delivered via 10 frozen meals per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a low-energy, high-protein diet on OSA severity and metabolic parameters in obese men.
results_summary: Both low-protein and high-protein diets led to significant weight loss and improvements in OSA severity and metabolic parameters, with no additional benefits from increased protein intake.
population_specificity: Obese men with Obstructive Sleep Apnea (BMI ≥ 30 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a high-protein (HP) diet versus a low glycemic index (LGI) diet as initial energy-restricted diets on weight loss, fat mass loss, muscle mass preservation, and lipid profile.
results_summary: The HP diet resulted in greater fat mass loss (4.6 kg vs. 2.2 kg) compared to the LGI diet, preserved muscle mass, and improved lipid profile, though final weight loss was not significantly different when the HP diet was used first.
population_specificity: Overweight or obese sedentary adults aged 41.4 ± 11.0 years with a BMI of 33.6 ± 4.2 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of two weight-loss diets (including a high-protein diet) on gut microbiota composition and functional profile in obese individuals.
results_summary: The study found sex- and diet-specific changes in gut microbiota composition and metabolic pathways, with men and women showing different bacterial responses to the high-protein and low-fat diets. No matching bacterial changes were observed between the groups, suggesting differential benefits based on sex and diet type.
population_specificity: 55 men and 124 women with BMI > 25 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of an 8-week high-protein diet combined with exercise on TG/HDL ratio, WHtR, body fat, and body weight in individuals with BMI >25 kg/m².
results_summary: The study found that an 8-week high-protein diet and exercise intervention improved markers of insulin resistance (TG/HDL ratio) and central adiposity (WHtR), along with reductions in body fat and body weight.
population_specificity: 43 subjects with BMI >25 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how a high-protein diet affects the activity of cytochrome P450 enzymes, particularly CYP1A2, in drug metabolism.
results_summary: The study found that a high-protein diet increased the activity of CYP1A2, which may enhance the metabolism of certain drugs. No adverse effects or safety concerns related to high-protein diets were reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population inferred from systematic review scope).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of high-protein diets from different sources (animal vs. vegetable) on insulin sensitivity in obese individuals with insulin resistance.
results_summary: High-protein hypocaloric diets (both animal and vegetable sources) significantly improved insulin sensitivity, reduced fat mass, triglycerides, and inflammatory markers, and increased skeletal muscle mass after one month. Blood pressure decreased in most groups except the animal normal-protein group.
population_specificity: Eighty subjects with obesity (BMI ≥ 30 kg/m²) and insulin resistance.

study_goal: The researchers explored the effects of dietary modifications, including intermittent fasting, on gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) and associated mood dysregulations (MDs).
results_summary: The abstract highlights that intermittent fasting (IF) reduced maternal body weight, plasma glucose, and psychological distress in a case report, but does not specifically address high-protein diet effects.
population_specificity: Women with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) and associated mood dysregulations (MDs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify metabolite signatures associated with fat mass and weight loss in older adults on a high-protein diet.
results_summary: The study found eight metabolites that changed significantly during the intervention, with variation in weight loss and fat mass changes. Baseline α-aminoadipate levels were associated with changes in visceral adipose tissue mass.
population_specificity: Adults aged 65-80 years

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a calorie-restricted high-protein diet (HPD) on the gut microbiome in overweight and obese individuals compared to a normal-protein diet (NPD).
results_summary: The HPD significantly increased microbial diversity and altered microbial composition compared to the NPD, with both diets inducing taxonomic shifts from baseline.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese subjects (n=80)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and efficacy of a hypocaloric high-protein diet supplemented with β-cryptoxanthin in improving non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
results_summary: The high-protein diet with β-cryptoxanthin significantly reduced liver enzyme levels and achieved higher clinical remission rates (82.6%) compared to other groups, with only minor adverse events reported.
population_specificity: Iranian NAFLD outpatients (N=92).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of dietary patterns, including the Mediterranean-DASH diet, for managing metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: The study found that dietary modifications, particularly the Mediterranean-DASH diet, showed beneficial effects on metabolic syndrome conditions and individual parameters, outperforming low-fat and restricted diets. Energy restriction and physical activity improvements were also highlighted as crucial for managing metabolic disturbances.
population_specificity: Metabolic syndrome patients (characterized by abdominal obesity, dyslipidemia, low HDL-c, hypertension, and insulin resistance).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of high-protein diets on body composition, metabolic parameters, and appetite regulation in obese patients, with a focus on protein quantity, source, and specific amino acids.
results_summary: High-protein diets were found to promote lean mass maintenance and satiety in certain human age groups, while whey protein and plant-based diets showed favorable effects on obesity risk and metabolic parameters. Specific amino acids like BCAA, methionine, tryptophan, and glutamate positively influenced obesity parameters in rodent models, though human translation remains limited.
population_specificity: Obese patients and rodent models, with varying effects noted across age groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize evidence on the effects of a high-protein diet on appetite sensations in individuals with overweight and obesity.
results_summary: Six out of ten studies showed enhanced fullness or satiety with high-protein intake, particularly in interventions lasting 10-12 weeks. However, the low level of evidence due to protocol heterogeneity and high risk of bias suggests the need for further confirmation.
population_specificity: Individuals with overweight or obesity (excluding those with diabetes, cancer, or other specific conditions).
effective_dosage: Protein intake >1.2 g/kg/day or >25% of total daily energy content.
study_duration: Intervention periods ranged from 10-12 weeks in four studies; others varied.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if an early combination of enteral and high-protein parenteral nutrition (EN+PN) effectively achieves energy and protein goals in critically ill patients at high nutritional risk while avoiding overfeeding.
results_summary: The study proposes testing the efficacy of high-protein EN+PN versus low-protein EN alone in nutritionally high-risk ICU patients, with outcomes measured at ICU/hospital discharge and 6-month follow-up. Results are pending as the trial (EFFORTcombo) is yet to be conducted.
population_specificity: Critically ill patients at high nutritional risk in the ICU.
effective_dosage: High-protein group: ≥2.2 g/kg per day; low-protein group: ≤1.2 g/kg per day.
study_duration: Efforts to reach nutrition goals within 48-96 hours, with follow-up until 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the benefits of glutamine supplementation in a high-protein diet for reducing mucosal damage and improving quality of life in cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy and radiation.
results_summary: The study found that glutamine supplementation in a high-protein diet (10 grams/day) with disaccharides improved glutamine uptake by mucosal cells, reducing painful symptoms and ulceration in the head and neck region, esophagus, stomach, and small intestine. It also supported better nutrition and maintained quality of life.
population_specificity: Cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy and radiation.
effective_dosage: 10 grams/day of glutamine in a high-protein diet + disaccharides (sucrose and/or trehalose).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and feasibility of a ketogenic diet (KD) during acute care for spinal cord injury (SCI) and determine its effects on motor/sensory function, functional independence, and glycemic control.
results_summary: The study found that 5 weeks of KD improved upper extremity motor function and reduced serum levels of a neuroinflammatory blood protein compared to a standard hospital diet in SCI patients. The study also aims to quantify serum biomarkers linked to neurological recovery.
population_specificity: Acutely traumatic spinal cord injured participants (cervical 5 to thoracic 12), aged 18-60, with AIS grades A-C.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how genetically determined adiposity subtypes influence the effects of weight-loss diets, including high-protein diets, on glucose metabolism.
results_summary: The study found that distinct adiposity subtypes modified the effects of dietary protein on glucose metabolism, with higher WHR-only polygenic scores showing less increase in fasting glucose and less reduction in β-cell function when consuming an average-protein diet, while high-protein diets were associated with less decrease in β-cell function among those with lower WHR-only scores.
population_specificity: 692 overweight participants (84% white Americans)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of a high-protein diet (0.8-1.2 g/kg) in managing energy balance, body weight, and obesity-related outcomes.
results_summary: The study suggests that a medium-high protein diet (0.8-1.2 g/kg) supports food intake control, counters adaptive thermogenesis, and aids in weight management when combined with dietary restraint. Protein intake helps sustain satiety and fat-free mass while modulating energy expenditure.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion on obesity and weight management).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining HMB with a high-protein diet enhances resistance-training-induced gains in fat-free mass and strength compared to protein supplementation alone in untrained individuals.
results_summary: Both groups showed increases in whole-body and segmental fat-free mass, but the HMB group had greater gains in leg fat-free mass. No significant changes in fat mass were observed, and strength improved in both groups.
population_specificity: Sixteen healthy untrained men (22 ± 2 years).
effective_dosage: 60 g whey protein on training days, 30 g on non-training days; 3 g calcium HMB or placebo daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of a very low-calorie ketogenic diet (VLCKD) in patients with obesity, including those with mild kidney failure.
results_summary: The study found significant weight loss (nearly 20% of initial weight) and improved metabolic parameters without clinically relevant adverse effects on kidney or liver function. Notably, 27.7% of patients with mild renal failure experienced normalization of glomerular filtrate after the dietary intervention.
population_specificity: Ninety-two patients with obesity, including 38 with mild kidney failure and 54 without renal conditions (control group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and appropriateness of a hypocaloric, high-protein diet in ICU patients with overweight/obesity, considering metabolic demands and complications.
