results_summary: The study found that a hypocaloric, high-protein diet is beneficial for ICU patients with overweight/obesity, with aggressive protein intake (up to 3g/kg ideal body weight/day) recommended for severe cases. Higher fat and slower-digesting carbohydrates in enteral formulas may aid glucose control, and immunonutrient supplementation is advised for reducing inflammation.
population_specificity: ICU patients with overweight, obesity, or adiposity-based chronic disease.
effective_dosage: Up to 3g/kg ideal body weight per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of high-animal-protein (AP) and high-plant-protein (PP) diets on oxidative stress and antioxidant status in individuals with type 2 diabetes (T2DM).
results_summary: Both AP and PP diets similarly reduced plasma malondialdehyde levels, indicating reduced oxidative stress, and improved antioxidant status in obese individuals with T2DM. The study also analyzed gene expression in subcutaneous adipose tissue, though detailed results were not provided in the abstract.
population_specificity: 37 obese individuals (average age 64.3 years) with type 2 diabetes.
effective_dosage: 30 energy% protein (isocaloric diet, with 30% fat and 40% carbohydrates).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a high-protein diet combined with resistance training would result in better long-term weight maintenance compared to a conventional low-fat diet or a high-protein diet alone.
results_summary: The study hypothesized that the combination of a high-protein diet and resistance training would yield similar short-term weight loss but superior long-term weight maintenance compared to other dietary approaches, though specific results are not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Overweight or obese Chinese adults.
study_duration: 8-week intervention with a 24-week follow-up (and optional 48-week supplementary follow-up).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the role of a high-protein diet in reducing malnutrition and improving health outcomes for patients with cystic fibrosis.
results_summary: The study found that a high-energy, high-protein diet, alongside pancreatic enzyme replacement, effectively reduced malnutrition in cystic fibrosis patients. It was part of multifaceted clinical care advancements contributing to improved patient outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with cystic fibrosis, including adults and children.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess how genetic factors, measured by polygenic scores, influence changes in blood pressure among individuals assigned to different macronutrient diets, including a high-protein diet, over a 2-year period.
results_summary: Participants with lower polygenic scores for blood pressure showed greater reductions in systolic and diastolic blood pressure compared to those with higher scores, suggesting genetic factors may influence blood pressure response to dietary interventions. The study did not isolate high-protein diet effects but included it as one of four macronutrient variations.
population_specificity: 692 participants with varying genetic predispositions to blood pressure changes.
effective_dosage: Not specified (diets varied in macronutrient content but exact protein amounts not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of a high-protein diet in managing sarcopenia in cirrhotic patients and identify gaps in current nutritional therapy.
results_summary: The study highlights that cirrhotic patients are recommended a high-protein diet (1.5 g/kg/day) with specific caloric intake and meal timing, but acknowledges gaps in diagnostic criteria and optimal nutritional therapy for sarcopenia.
population_specificity: Patients with liver cirrhosis and sarcopenia.
effective_dosage: 1.5 g/kg/day of protein, 30-40 kcal/kg/day, with late evening snacks containing at least 50 g of carbohydrates.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the adherence and efficacy of a revised protein-sparing modified fast (rPSMF) for severe obesity in a pediatric weight-management program.
results_summary: The rPSMF resulted in clinically significant weight loss at 1, 3, and 6 months, though weight loss diminished by 12 months. Parent and child-reported physical and psychosocial quality of life improved despite limited adherence.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents (mean age 16.2 years, 76.2% female) with severe obesity.
effective_dosage: 1200-1800 calories, 40-60 g carbohydrate/day, and 1.2-1.5 g protein/kg of ideal bodyweight.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of a high-protein and low-carbohydrate diet versus a standard hypocaloric diet on biochemical changes after weight loss, focusing on the genetic variant rs1501299 in the ADIPOQ gene.
results_summary: Both diets led to weight loss and improvements in metabolic parameters, but non-T-allele carriers (GG genotype) showed greater improvements in adiponectin levels, insulin resistance, and lipid profile compared to T-allele carriers. The high-protein diet was particularly effective in reducing total cholesterol, LDL cholesterol, triacylglycerol, insulin levels, and insulin resistance in non-T-allele carriers.
population_specificity: 270 obese white patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if pre-treatment metabolic markers (FPG, FI, HOMA-IR) could predict long-term weight loss outcomes in diets varying in carbohydrate, fat, and protein content, while assessing dietary fiber intake.
results_summary: Subjects with FPG <100 mg/dL lost 2.6 kg (95% CI 0.9;4.4), suggesting metabolic markers may influence weight loss response to macronutrient composition, but the abstract does not specify High-Protein Diet results separately.
population_specificity: Participants from the POUNDS LOST trial (specific demographics not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a high-protein total diet replacement versus a control diet on energy expenditure, macronutrient oxidation rates, metabolic blood markers, and appetite sensations in healthy adults.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results, as the study is described as ongoing or not yet completed.
population_specificity: Healthy young adults (both sexes)
effective_dosage: High-protein total diet replacement: 35% carbohydrate, 40% protein, 25% fat

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether an energy-restricted high-protein diet (35% protein) improves insulin resistance and glucose metabolism in overweight/obese individuals with type 2 diabetes compared to a standard-protein diet (18% protein).
results_summary: The high-protein diet led to a 2-fold greater reduction in HOMA-IR, lower insulin and glucose levels, and higher adiponectin increases compared to the standard-protein diet, though adipokine changes did not fully explain the metabolic improvements. Both diets resulted in similar weight loss.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese adults (mean BMI 32.8 ± 3.67) with type 2 diabetes (mean age 55.6 ± 8.37, 43.8% male).
effective_dosage: High-protein diet: 35% of total calories (1.34 [95%CI: 1.27-1.41] g/kg/day); Standard-protein diet: 18% of total calories (0.75 [95%CI: 0.71-0.78] g/kg/day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of the Hipcref diet (high-protein, energy-restricted, high-vitamin E, and high-fibre) on body composition and metabolic parameters in overweight/obese Malaysian adults over 6 months.
results_summary: The Hipcref diet group showed significant reductions in weight, BMI, waist circumference, fat mass, percentage body fat, fasting insulin, insulin resistance, and C-reactive protein levels compared to the control group. The control group experienced significant increases in weight and BMI.
population_specificity: Overweight/obese Malaysian adults (BMI ≥23 kg/m², n=128).
effective_dosage: Not specified (diet charts based on personal preferences).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility of protein restriction in elderly patients with advanced kidney disease through individualized dietary approaches.
results_summary: The study found that protein restriction was feasible in an elderly, high-comorbidity population with stable nutritional status, with most patients opting for normalization of protein intake (0.8 g/kg/day) or moderate restriction (0.6 g/kg/day) via traditional or plant-based diets. Compliance was monitored, but specific efficacy outcomes were not detailed.
population_specificity: Elderly patients (median age 74) with advanced kidney disease, high comorbidity (Charlson Index 8), and varying eGFR levels; excluded those with protein energy wasting or short life expectancy.
effective_dosage: Normalization (0.8 g/kg/day), moderate restriction (0.6 g/kg/day) with traditional or plant-based diets supplemented with ketoacids.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of nonmeat, high-protein supplementation on health-related quality of life and clinical/nutritional outcomes in older care home residents.
results_summary: The study found no significant improvement in HRQOL using the SF-36, but one trial using EQ-5D showed significant improvement. Nonmeat, high-protein supplements improved nutritional markers, but evidence on HRQOL was insufficient due to low/moderate study quality.
population_specificity: Care home residents aged 65 years or older.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of high-protein diets (HPD) on metabolic outcomes, gut microbiota, and large intestine mucosa homeostasis in overweight and obese individuals.
results_summary: HPD generally reduced body weight and improved blood metabolic parameters but altered fecal and urinary bacterial metabolites. Effects on gut microbiota varied by diet type, and HPD modified gene expression in rectal mucosa without causing inflammation, with outcomes differing by protein source (plant vs. animal).
population_specificity: Overweight and obese individuals

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a high-protein diet combined with concurrent exercise training (CET) or resistance training (RES) affects muscle strength, hypertrophy, and anaerobic power adaptations.
results_summary: The study found that both CET and RES groups showed significant increases in leg press strength (~24-33%), total lean mass (~4%), and vastus lateralis volume (~11-15%), with no differences between groups. However, anaerobic power adaptations showed a trend toward greater improvement in the RES group, suggesting potential interference effects with CET.
population_specificity: Thirty-two recreationally active males (age 25 ± 5 years, BMI 24 ± 3 kg·m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a low-calorie high-protein diet (HP) versus a low-calorie standard-protein diet (SP) on waist circumference in visceral obese adults with a history of weight cycling.
results_summary: Both HP and SP diets significantly reduced waist circumference, but there was no statistically significant difference in the mean reduction between the two groups, indicating that protein proportion did not significantly affect waist circumference.
population_specificity: Visceral obese adults with a history of weight cycling.
effective_dosage: HP group: 22-30% of total calorie intake as protein; SP group: 12-20% of total calorie intake as protein.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a high-protein diet affects whole body and lumbar bone mineral content in exercise-trained women.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in whole body bone mineral density, lumbar bone mineral density, T-scores, lean body mass, or fat mass between the high-protein and control groups, despite an 87% higher protein intake in the high-protein group.
population_specificity: Exercise-trained women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a high-protein diet could preserve muscle mass and function in older adults undergoing caloric restriction for weight loss.
results_summary: The high-protein diet led to significant total body and fat mass loss while preserving lean body mass and mobility, though no differential treatment effect was observed for lean mass changes. Gait speed showed a slight trend toward improvement in the weight loss group compared to the weight stability group.
population_specificity: Older adults (70.3 ± 3.7 years, 74% women, 27% African American) with obesity (BMI 35.4 ± 3.3 kg/m², 47% total body fat).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review recent clinical research on the effects of high-protein diets on calcium metabolism and bone health.
results_summary: High-protein intake is positively associated with bone mineral density and reduced fracture risk, with no negative impact on calcium homeostasis. The acid load from protein is offset by its skeletal benefits.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population inferred from epidemiological and interventional studies).
study_duration: Not specified (short-term interventional studies mentioned, but exact duration not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a high-protein diet versus a low-protein diet in conjunction with an 8-week resistance training program for aspiring female physique athletes.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of the high-protein diet, only stating that the study examined its influence.
population_specificity: Aspiring female physique athletes (17 females, aged 21.2 ± 2.1 years, height 165.1 ± 5.1 cm, weight 61 ± 6.1 kg).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the compatibility of a high-protein diet with pregnancy in a patient with Primary Intestinal Lymphangiectasia (PIL) and its impact on managing symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that strict adherence to a low-fat/high-protein diet with MCT supplementation helped manage PIL symptoms during pregnancy, though complications arose in late gestation. Post-delivery, symptoms resolved rapidly, and both mother and infant were healthy at follow-up.
population_specificity: A 34-year-old pregnant woman with endoscopically diagnosed PIL.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of increased protein intake on weight loss and metabolic biomarkers in Mexican adults with metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: The high-protein diet (HPD) group lost more weight (7.0 kg) than the standard protein diet (SPD) group (5.1 kg), with greater weight loss in adherent HPD participants (-9.5% vs. -5.8%). Both groups showed improvements in waist circumference and some metabolic biomarkers, but no significant differences between groups overall.
population_specificity: Mexican adults aged 47.4 ± 11.5 years with metabolic syndrome.
effective_dosage: 1.34 g/kg body weight (HPD) vs. 0.8 g/kg body weight (SPD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether high-protein diets improve glycemic outcomes in people with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2D).
results_summary: Many studies supported high-protein diets for T2D, but results were mixed, with randomized controlled trials often showing no difference compared to controls. No consistent beneficial or detrimental effects on renal or cardiovascular outcomes were found.
population_specificity: People with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2D).
effective_dosage: Protein content >16% of total energy (most tested diets had ~30% protein).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of a high-protein, high-fiber diet combined with BCAA supplementation in improving nutritional status and metabolic markers in patients with cirrhosis.
results_summary: The study found that the intervention increased muscle mass and reduced fat mass without raising ammonia or glucose levels or causing hepatic encephalopathy, demonstrating safety and some efficacy. No significant adverse effects were reported.
population_specificity: Patients with cirrhosis (72 participants, 37 in the intervention group and 35 in the control group).
effective_dosage: 1.2g/kg protein and 30g fiber daily, plus 110g oral BCAAs daily for the intervention group.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility, tolerability, and efficacy of a low glycaemic index high-protein diet (LGHP) as a weight loss maintenance strategy following rapid weight loss in obese adults with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).
results_summary: The study compared the LGHP diet to the Australian Guide to Healthy Eating diet (AGHE) over a 10-month follow-up period after initial rapid weight loss via a 2-month very low energy diet (VLED). The abstract does not provide specific efficacy results for the LGHP diet, but the study design suggests it was evaluated for weight maintenance in OSA patients.
population_specificity: Obese adult patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare gene expression changes in white adipose tissue between a high-protein diet and a normal-protein diet during energy restriction, and to assess the overall effects of energy restriction on gene expression.
results_summary: The study found that a normal-protein diet during energy restriction led to downregulation of inflammation-related genes, while a high-protein diet upregulated genes linked to cell cycle and metabolism. Energy restriction itself reduced gene sets related to energy metabolism and immune response.
population_specificity: Overweight older adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of a low-calorie, high-protein diet with and without a thermogenic supplement on body weight and body composition in healthy females.
results_summary: The study found that both the high-protein diet with a thermogenic supplement (BURN) and the diet alone (PLA) led to significant reductions in body weight and total body fat mass compared to the control group, with no significant adverse effects on blood pressure, heart rate, or clinical safety markers.
population_specificity: Apparently healthy females (N = 39, divided into three groups).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the association of dietary protein intake markers, adherence measures, and demographic variables with weight loss over 6 and 24 months in participants assigned to different macronutrient diets.
results_summary: Greater divergence between baseline and follow-up protein intake (measured via urinary nitrogen excretion) was linked to increased weight loss over 2 years. Older age, male gender, and higher BMI (>30 kg/m²) were also associated with weight loss at 6 and 24 months.
population_specificity: Participants in the POUNDS Lost study assigned to one of four macronutrient diets.
effective_dosage: Diets included 15%P (AP/LF, AP/HF) and 25%P (HP/LF, HP/HF) protein intake.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the effects of a high-protein diet on insulin resistance and β cell function vary based on genetic susceptibility to diabetes.
results_summary: The study found that individuals with a higher genetic risk of diabetes may benefit more from a high-protein diet in reducing fasting insulin, while those with lower genetic risk may benefit more from a low-protein diet for improving insulin resistance and β cell function.
population_specificity: 744 overweight or obese nondiabetic adults (80% white Americans).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a standard-protein (0.8 g/kg/day) versus a high-protein (1.2 g/kg/day) hypocaloric diet on muscle insulin action and lean tissue mass preservation in postmenopausal women with obesity during weight loss.
results_summary: The high-protein diet reduced lean tissue mass loss by ~45% but prevented weight-loss-induced improvements in muscle insulin signaling, glucose uptake, and adaptations in oxidative stress and cell structural biology pathways.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women with obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of three energy-reduced diets with varying protein percentages (20%, 27%, and 35%) on weight loss, lipids, acceptability, and compliance.
results_summary: The 35% protein diet showed a more favorable impact on cardiometabolic profile compared to lower-protein diets, though no significant difference in overall weight loss was observed. The high-protein diet had excellent safety and acceptability.
population_specificity: Women aged 18-80 years with BMI 27.5-45 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the long-term effects of early dietary intervention, specifically comparing reduced-protein infant formula to high-protein diets, on obesity risk and related metabolic markers.
results_summary: The study found that infant formula with reduced protein content resulted in lower BMI at 2 and 6 years, mediated by branched-chain amino acids affecting the IGF-1 axis and insulin release. High-protein diets were associated with larger kidney size, linked to free IGF-1, but the role of leptin and adiponectin in infancy for later obesity risk remains unclear.
population_specificity: Infants (studied at 2 and 6 years of age).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a new compartmental model to describe lean- and fat-mass growth based on dietary protein and fat intake, accounting for their interdependence.
results_summary: The new model showed smoother data fit with lower error compared to the Forbes model, with statistically significant differences in coefficients across diets, suggesting better predictive accuracy for lean- and fat-mass changes.
population_specificity: 23 normal participants in an overfeeding trial (high-protein, normal-protein, and low-protein diets).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review recent literature on noma and update information on its treatment, including the use of a high-protein diet.
results_summary: The study found that a high-protein diet is part of the treatment for acute noma, alongside blood transfusions, intravenous fluids, antibiotics, and debridement. No specific outcomes related to the high-protein diet were detailed.
population_specificity: Malnourished children, HIV patients, and individuals with conditions like cyclic neutropenia, herpetic stomatitis, leukemia, Down's syndrome, and Burkett's disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a high-protein diet, combined with resistance-vibrating exercise, could mitigate adverse effects of immobilization on the coagulation system.
results_summary: The study found that high-protein supplementation did not worsen clotting during immobilization, with similar coagulation changes observed across all groups. However, re-ambulation showed a tendency toward hypercoagulation, suggesting a potential thrombotic risk post-immobilization.
population_specificity: 11 healthy men undergoing 21-day head-down bed rest.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine best practices for managing alcohol hepatitis, including the role of a high-protein diet in patient recovery.
results_summary: The study recommends a high-protein diet (1-1.5 g/kg body weight) for patients with alcohol hepatitis to support adequate recovery, particularly when combined with abstinence and nutritional supplementation.
population_specificity: Patients with alcohol hepatitis, particularly those with jaundice or severe cases (MELD score > 20 or MDF > 32).
effective_dosage: 1-1.5 g protein per kg body weight daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of high-protein diets in weight loss and maintenance, as well as assess potential long-term health consequences.
results_summary: High-protein diets were found to enhance satiety, reduce food intake, and promote weight loss and decreased adiposity. While potentially harmful for individuals with kidney dysfunction, there was little evidence of danger for healthy individuals.
population_specificity: Healthy individuals and those with existing kidney dysfunction (mentioned for comparison).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a high-protein diet combined with carbohydrate restriction and behavioral therapy in maintaining weight loss among overweight and obese patients managed by primary care physicians.
results_summary: 26.7% of patients successfully maintained a 10% weight loss beyond one year, with greater initial BMI and fat mass percentage correlating with success. Frequent consultations and initial weight loss were key determinants of success.
population_specificity: Patients with BMI > 25 kg/m² (overweight and obese) managed by primary care physicians.
study_duration: Follow-up beyond 1 year (exact intervention duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of dietary proteins and carbohydrates on markers of endothelial dysfunction (ED) and low-grade inflammation (LGI) in overweight/obese individuals with untreated elevated blood pressure.
results_summary: The high-protein diet significantly improved fasting ED markers (Z-scores and sICAM) after 4 weeks, but no clear differences were observed in postprandial ED and LGI responses between protein sources or carbohydrates. Postprandial sVCAM decreased more after protein mix compared to maltodextrin.
population_specificity: Overweight/obese individuals with untreated elevated blood pressure.
effective_dosage: 3×20 g/d protein mix or maltodextrin (Study 1); 0.6 g/kg pea protein, milk protein, and egg-white protein (Study 2).

study_goal: To investigate the effects of protein-enriched bread and drinking yoghurt on total protein intake and its distribution over the day in older adults.
results_summary: The intervention group had significantly higher protein intake (115.3 g/d vs. 72.5 g/d) and met recommended protein levels per meal, while the control group fell below recommendations during breakfast and lunch.
population_specificity: Older adults (≥55 years) admitted to a rehabilitation center after hospital discharge (n=34).
effective_dosage: Protein-enriched bread and drinking yoghurt (specific amounts not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of a moderately high protein diet on bone mineral density (BMD) and other metabolic markers in older adults.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in BMD changes between the protein and control groups, but the protein group showed increased truncal lean mass and higher levels of certain metabolic markers (C-terminal telopeptide, IGF-1, urinary urea) without adverse effects on renal function.
population_specificity: Older women and men (n=208) with a BMI of 19-32 kg/m² and self-reported protein intake of 0.6-1.0 g/kg.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the metabolic response to higher or lower protein intake in infancy and its potential link to obesity risk.
results_summary: The study found that higher protein intake in infants led to elevated branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs) and their degradation products, suggesting a possible saturation of the BCAA degradation pathway, which may inhibit β-oxidation and promote fat storage.
population_specificity: 6-month-old infants (691 participants) receiving either higher-protein (HP) or lower-protein (LP) formula or breast milk.
effective_dosage: HP formula (2.05 g per 100 mL), LP formula (1.25 g per 100 mL).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term treatment outcomes of high-protein diets in patients with glycogen storage disease (GSD) types VI and IX, focusing on potential prevention of complications.
results_summary: The study identified novel mutations and reported liver and cardiac complications in GSD-VI and -IX patients but did not conclusively demonstrate the efficacy of high-protein diets in preventing these complications, calling for further research.
population_specificity: 21 patients with confirmed diagnoses of GSD-VI or -IX.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a high-protein low-carbohydrate diet (HPLC) prevents a positive energy balance compared to a high-carbohydrate low-protein diet (HCLP) at a constant body weight, and whether its effects on fullness, energy expenditure, and macronutrient balances are transient or sustained over 12 weeks.
results_summary: The HPLC diet maintained total energy expenditure (TEE) and energy balance, while the HCLP diet led to decreased TEE and a positive energy balance. Fullness was higher in the HPLC group initially but not sustained at 12 weeks, and protein balance directly reflected dietary protein intake.
population_specificity: 14 men and 18 women (mean age 24 ± 5 y, BMI 22.8 ± 2.0 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: 30% protein, 35% carbohydrate, 35% fat (HPLC) vs. 5% protein, 60% carbohydrate, 35% fat (HCLP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a hypocaloric high-protein diet on lipid profile, glucose homeostasis, and liver enzymes in patients with NAFLD, independent of BMI or body fat reduction.
results_summary: The study found that a hypocaloric high-protein diet improved HDL-cholesterol, reduced total, LDL, and VLDL cholesterol, triglycerides, liver enzymes (AST, GGT, AP), fasting blood glucose, and HbA1c. Weight loss was associated with additional liver benefits, but improvements occurred even without BMI or fat mass reduction.
population_specificity: 48 stable NAFLD patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a high-protein diet on metabolic improvement in patients with type 2 diabetes, comparing it with other dietary regimens.
results_summary: The study found that a high-protein diet improved metabolic conditions in patients with type 2 diabetes, though the degree of improvement varied among individuals. Tailoring the diet to individual pathophysiological characteristics was emphasized for optimal efficacy.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify obese subjects who would lose weight and maintain weight loss through a high-protein diet and energy restriction, and to determine predictors of weight trajectories.
results_summary: The study identified three clusters of subjects based on weight loss and maintenance, with clusters A and B showing better outcomes. Weight regain correlated with baseline insulin resistance and inflammatory markers, suggesting these factors predict resistance to weight loss and proneness to regain.
population_specificity: Fifty obese or overweight subjects.
study_duration: 6 weeks of energy-restricted, high-protein diet followed by 6 weeks of weight maintenance.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether specific amino acids (CaSR-AAAs or DAAs) or dietary protein as a whole are responsible for stimulating intestinal calcium absorption.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in calcium absorption between the CaSR-AAA-supplemented diet and the control diet, but calcium absorption tended to be greater with DAA supplementation compared to the control. Larger trials are needed to confirm the potential benefit of arginine and lysine on calcium absorption.
population_specificity: 14 young women
effective_dosage: Low-protein diet (0.7 g/kg) supplemented with CaSR-AAAs (L-tryptophan, L-phenylalanine, L-histidine) or DAAs (L-arginine, L-lysine) to match high-protein diet intake (2.1 g/kg).
study_duration: 6-day intervention periods after an 11-day adjustment period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a high-protein diet enriched with β-hydroxy-β-methylbutyrate, calcium, and vitamin D, combined with rehabilitation, improves functional recovery in elderly patients after hip fracture surgery.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results but outlines the study's objectives to assess functional recovery, body composition changes, sarcopenia prevalence, and mortality one year post-fracture, as well as potential links between inflammatory markers and functional outcomes.
population_specificity: Elderly patients (aged 65 or above) who underwent surgery for traumatic hip fracture.

study_goal: To determine the feasibility and efficacy of a high-protein diet compared with a standard diet for weight maintenance, insulin requirement, and metabolic parameters in insulin-treated type-2 diabetic patients over 12 weeks.
results_summary: The high-protein diet significantly reduced insulin requirement, fasting plasma glucose, body mass index, fat-free mass, and fat mass while increasing serum folate compared to the standard diet, with no significant differences in renal function. These benefits were likely due to achieved weight loss.
population_specificity: Insulin-treated type-2 diabetic patients (n=44).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of different dietary compositions, including a high-protein diet, on anthropometric, reproductive, metabolic, and psychological outcomes in women with PCOS.
results_summary: The study found that a high-protein diet improved depression and self-esteem in women with PCOS, though it did not specifically highlight other metabolic or reproductive benefits compared to other diets.
population_specificity: Women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) not taking anti-obesity medications.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the short-term and long-term effects of a high-protein diet versus a standard-protein diet on body weight, adiposity, cardiac function, glycemic control, and quality of life in overweight/obese individuals with heart failure and type 2 diabetes or metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: The study compared a high-protein diet (30% protein) to a standard-protein diet (15% protein) over 3 months, with follow-up at 15 months, but the abstract does not report specific outcomes regarding efficacy.
population_specificity: Overweight/obese individuals with heart failure and type 2 diabetes or metabolic syndrome (mean age 58.2 ± 9.8 years; 73.1% male).
effective_dosage: High-protein diet: 30% protein (~110 g/day), 40% carbohydrates (150 g/day), 30% fat (~50 g/day); Standard-protein diet: 15% protein (~55 g/day), 55% carbohydrates (~200 g/day), 30% fat (~50 g/day).
study_duration: 3-month intensive intervention, with data collected at baseline, 3 months, and 15 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of high-protein diets on weight loss, weight maintenance, and metabolic syndrome parameters, while assessing potential risks.
results_summary: High-protein diets (0.8-1.2 g/kg BW) improved satiety, energy expenditure, and body composition, reduced blood pressure, and prevented weight regain without kidney issues in healthy individuals. The benefits were attributed to protein content rather than carbohydrate restriction.
population_specificity: Individuals with obesity or metabolic syndrome (healthy individuals for safety assessment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the FTO genotype interacts with dietary protein intake to influence weight loss, body composition, and fat distribution in obese adults.
results_summary: The study found that carriers of the FTO risk allele had greater reductions in weight, body composition, and fat distribution when following a high-protein diet, while an opposite effect was observed with a low-protein diet. Significant interactions were noted at both 6 months and 2 years.
population_specificity: 742 obese adults with genotyping for FTO rs1558902.
effective_dosage: Not specified (diets varied in proportions of fat, protein, and carbohydrate).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a high-protein diet on kidney function, specifically glomerular filtration rate (eGFR), in healthy adults with prehypertension or stage 1 hypertension.
results_summary: The high-protein diet increased cystatin C-based eGFR by approximately 4 mL/min/1.73 m² compared to carbohydrate and unsaturated fat diets, with no significant difference between the latter two diets. The effects were independent of blood pressure changes, but long-term implications for kidney disease risk remain uncertain.
population_specificity: Healthy adults (N=164) with prehypertension or stage 1 hypertension.
effective_dosage: 25% of energy intake from protein (compared to 15% in the other diets).
study_duration: 6 weeks per diet, with 2- to 4-week washout periods between diets.

study_goal: To investigate the effects of a 3-month hypocaloric low-fat/high-protein diet combined with physical activity on insulin sensitivity and cardiometabolic factors in obese patients.
results_summary: The intervention improved insulin sensitivity and metabolic factors in insulin-resistant obese patients (group 3), while insulin-sensitive obese patients (group 1) experienced worsened glucose levels. Weight loss and metabolic benefits were observed in insulin-resistant individuals.
population_specificity: 263 obese women and 93 obese men.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of high-protein diets in long-term randomized clinical trials, focusing on weight loss compared to conventional or high-fat/high-carbohydrate diets.
results_summary: High-protein diets showed modest weight loss benefits (average 6.3 kg vs. 5.0 kg in standard diets), but results were inconsistent, with longer-term studies showing no statistical difference in weight loss. The long-term effect of high-protein diets was neither consistent nor conclusive.
population_specificity: Adults in randomized clinical trials with intervention/follow-up of at least 24 weeks.
effective_dosage: Specific percentages of energy protein in the diet (not quantified in abstract).
study_duration: Ranged from 6 months (24 weeks) to 17 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of overconsumption of low, normal, and high protein diets on weight gain, energy expenditure, and body composition.
results_summary: Overeating with a high-protein diet led to greater weight gain (6.51 kg) compared to a low-protein diet (3.16 kg), with increased lean body mass and energy expenditure but no difference in body fat storage.
population_specificity: 25 healthy, weight-stable US volunteers aged 18-35 with a BMI of 19-30.
effective_dosage: Diets containing 5% (low), 15% (normal), or 25% (high) of energy from protein, overfed by ~40% (954 kcal/day).
study_duration: 8 weeks of overfeeding during a 10-12 week inpatient stay.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether sex influences the biochemical and growth responses to different protein intakes (higher vs. lower) in formula-fed infants during early life.
results_summary: The study found that a high-protein diet modulated the IGF-1 axis differently by sex, with girls showing a stronger endocrine response (higher IGF-1 and lower IGF binding protein 2) than boys, though no enhanced growth effects were observed. The HP diet also increased the C-peptide/creatinine ratio and leptin levels were higher in girls.
population_specificity: Formula-fed infants (both sexes) during the first 6 months of life.
effective_dosage: Not specified (higher protein vs. lower protein formula content).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of low versus high protein status on food intake and preferences, specifically whether compensatory mechanisms exist to restore protein balance.
results_summary: The study found that after a low-protein diet, protein intake increased by 13% during the ad libitum phase, with enhanced preferences for savory high-protein foods, suggesting adaptive behavioral strategies to restore protein status. Total energy intake remained unchanged.
population_specificity: 37 subjects (mean age 21 ± 2 years, BMI 21.9 ± 1.5 kg/m²)
effective_dosage: Low-protein diet (0.5 g protein/kg BW/day) and high-protein diet (2.0 g protein/kg BW/day)
study_duration: 14-day dietary intervention followed by a 2.5-day ad libitum phase

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the signaling and metabolic roles of leucine in high-protein diets, particularly its effects on protein synthesis, energy balance, and glucose regulation.
results_summary: The study found that leucine, a key component of high-protein diets, activates mTOR signaling to promote protein synthesis in skeletal muscle and adipose tissue, regulates food intake response, and aids in glucose regulation and lean mass retention during caloric restriction.
population_specificity: Not specified (abstract suggests potential applicability to animals and humans).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify blood profiles associated with weight loss/regain and biomarkers of dietary protein and GI levels during weight maintenance.
results_summary: A high-protein and low-GI diet improved weight maintenance, with specific blood biomarkers (e.g., leptin, CRP) linked to weight regain. Dietary protein levels influenced these relationships.
population_specificity: Female participants (n=96) from four dietary groups, evenly split between continued weight losers and regainers.
study_duration: 6-month dietary intervention after 8-week weight loss phase

study_goal: The researchers were examining the role of high-protein diet as a precipitating factor for hepatic encephalopathy (HE) in patients with liver disease.
results_summary: The abstract indicates that a high-protein diet is one of several factors that can exacerbate hepatic encephalopathy, contributing to oxidative/nitrosative stress and astrocyte swelling in the brain. However, the study does not provide specific data on the magnitude or mechanisms of this effect.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic or acute liver disease, particularly those at risk for hepatic encephalopathy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if additional dietary protein improves lean tissue deposition and carcass merit in pigs supplemented with creatine monohydrate and dextrose.
results_summary: Barrows on the high-protein combination diet (COMBOHP) showed reduced 10th rib fat and higher fat-free carcass lean, while gilts showed no significant differences. Meat quality parameters were unaffected in both sexes.
population_specificity: Crossbred barrows and gilts (pigs) weighing approximately 91 kg.
effective_dosage: COMBOHP diet formulated to contain a minimum of 16% crude protein, supplemented with 0.92% creatine monohydrate and 2.75% dextrose.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether high-protein diets are superior to high-carbohydrate diets for improving glycaemic control in individuals with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Both high-protein and high-carbohydrate diets resulted in similar reductions in HbA(1c), weight, serum triacylglycerol, and total cholesterol, with no significant differences between groups. No superior long-term metabolic benefits of a high-protein diet were observed.
population_specificity: Overweight/obese individuals (BMI 27-40 kg/m²) with type 2 diabetes (HbA(1c) 6.5-10%).
effective_dosage: High-protein diet (30% total energy), high-carbohydrate diet (55% total energy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether high-protein and low-glycemic-index diets improve study completion and weight-loss maintenance compared to other dietary approaches.
results_summary: The study found that high-protein and low-glycemic-index diets resulted in less weight regain and higher study completion rates compared to low-protein-high-glycemic-index diets. The high-protein diet showed statistically significant benefits in weight maintenance.
population_specificity: Overweight adults from eight European countries who had lost at least 8% of their initial body weight with a low-calorie diet.
effective_dosage: Ad libitum diets (specific protein or glycemic index modifications, exact amounts not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether a high-protein diet could benefit obese individuals, particularly those undergoing surgery, and assess potential adverse effects.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that high-protein diets, modeled after the Atkins approach, are widely used but does not provide specific findings on efficacy or safety. It raises questions about benefits for obese patients in medical and surgical settings.
population_specificity: Obese subjects, including those in clinical trials and potentially surgical patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a high-protein diet versus a conventional protein diet on weight loss, weight maintenance, and body composition in individuals with metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: The high-protein diet group lost more body weight and fat mass than the conventional protein diet group, with similar fat-free mass loss in both groups. Improvements in metabolic syndrome parameters were greater in the high-protein group, with 64.5% no longer meeting metabolic syndrome criteria after 12 months.
population_specificity: Obese individuals with metabolic syndrome.
effective_dosage: High-protein diet (1.34 g/kg body weight) vs. conventional protein diet (0.8 g/kg body weight).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of a high-protein diet in managing protein-losing enteropathy (PLE) by maintaining nutritional status and addressing hypoproteinemia.
results_summary: The study found that a high-protein diet, supplemented with fat-soluble vitamins, is part of the treatment for PLE to counteract protein loss, with specific dietary adjustments like low-fat MCT diets for lymphangiectasia patients.
population_specificity: Patients with protein-losing enteropathy (PLE), particularly those with gastrointestinal or cardiac conditions causing excessive protein loss.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to report a rare case of traumatic posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) aneurysm and hypoglossal nerve palsy resulting from a hiking-related fall.
results_summary: The study described a 67-year-old man who suffered fractures and a PICA aneurysm after a hiking fall, leading to delayed hypoglossal nerve palsy and subarachnoid hemorrhage. Stent-assisted coil embolization was successful, and the patient was transferred to rehabilitation.
population_specificity: 67-year-old male hiker with traumatic injuries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a very low-carbohydrate, high-protein diet (VLCD) versus a conventional restrictive diet (CONV) on strength performance in sedentary women.
results_summary: Both diets led to significant body mass reduction without significant differences between them. Neither diet impaired acute strength performance, as measured by knee extension isokinetic strength tests.
population_specificity: Sedentary women
effective_dosage: VLCD (<40 g carbohydrate); CONV (500-800 kcal restrictive, 48% carb, 22% protein, 30% fat)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether iodine supplementation could reduce the negative effects of endocrine disruptors on reproductive, perinatal, and obstetric outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that iodine supplementation, among other interventions, was effective in reducing exposure to endocrine disruptors, though data on clinical outcomes were limited.
population_specificity: Human populations, though specific demographics are not detailed in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of iodine-125 brachytherapy as an alternative treatment for central mucoepidermoid carcinoma of the jaw, particularly in preserving jaw integrity and function in teenagers.
results_summary: The study found that iodine-125 brachytherapy successfully treated intraosseous MEC of the mandible in an 11-year-old girl, with no local recurrence or distant metastasis observed over 6 years. The treatment preserved mandible integrity and did not significantly affect its development.
population_specificity: 11-year-old girl with central mucoepidermoid carcinoma of the mandible.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of iodine and iodine-analog isotopes in diagnosing and treating thyroid diseases, particularly in identifying autonomously functioning thyroid tissue.
results_summary: The study found that thyroid imaging with iodine or iodine-analog isotopes is effective for diagnosing thyrotoxicosis and identifying autonomously functioning thyroid tissue, which strongly indicates benign conditions. It also highlighted the continued importance of nuclear medicine methods in thyroid nodule evaluation.
population_specificity: Patients with thyrotoxicosis and thyroid nodules.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the tolerance and acceptability of iodine-based handscrubbing (10% iodopovidone) versus alcohol-based handrubbing among surgeons.
results_summary: The study found minimal variation in skin tolerance between iodine-based handscrubbing and alcohol-based handrubbing, but alcohol-based handrubbing was significantly preferred for acceptability factors like smell, texture, and overall satisfaction.
population_specificity: Cardiac and orthopedic surgeons (94% male, mean age 35 years) at an academic quaternary care hospital in Brazil.
